summary: no effective antiviral strategies are yet available for viruses causing chronic infections such as HBV [2], as well as for tropical viruses like dengue virus that is causing 390 million infections per year. despite the huge effort to find antivirals, the research community was not able to execute in time an efficient antiviral plan. in this scenario, the possibility to find antiviral molecules directed against viral envelopes is of particular interest in order to identify broad spectrum antiviral drugs. virolytic antiviral peptides derived from mastoparan were shown to inhibit different enveloped viruses acting on the envelope and causing its detachment from the viral core [14]. virolytic antiviral peptides derived from mastoparan were shown to inhibit different enveloped viruses acting on the envelope and causing its detachment from the viral core. evenagel condensation with aldehyde 4 or 6 in refluxing acidic EtOH led to compounds 15a and 15b. rhodanine derivatives belonging to this series of compounds are potential microbicide active against HIV-1 and HSV-1/2. compounds were tested with a plaquing efficiency assay, preincubating with the virus for 1 h at 37°C. compound 9d showed a potent antiviral activity against all enveloped viruses tested at not cytotoxic doses. compound 9d retained its antiviral activity also against HSV-2 acyclo. type of virus EC50* was added on cells before the virus in order to determine if the antiviral activity was due to an interaction with the cells. results showed that the antiviral activity of 9d is not due to an interaction with cells, since the compound was not active in pre-treatment assays. we observed a significant reduction of activity in the during-infection assay (EC50 = 0.147 M) suggesting that the loss of activity could be related to a competition between the viral envelope and the cell membrane. ants and cells were harvested and subsequently titrated with plaque assay. percentage of infection was calculated comparing viral titer in treated wells and wells treated with equal volumes of solvent. viral titers were calculated at dilutions of compounds at which, in plaquing efficiency assay, did not show any inhibitory activity. the percentage of infection was calculated comparing viral titer in treated wells and wells treated with equal volumes of solvent. cells were subjected to qPCR (A) or immunostaining (B) or IF (C) subsequently cells were fixed and subjected to ICC (D) or IF (E). UT = untreated ** p0.001 *** p0.0005 **** p0.0001. p0.01 NaCl 0.9% and DMSO are blank samples prepared without the addition of 9d and ()--tocopherol. aldehydes 4–6 were obtained using the one pot two step approach previously generated by us for the synthesis of rhodanine derivatives. l chloride 10, ammonium thiocyanate and the opportune amine led to intermediates 11a and 11b; consequent hydrazinolisis and coupling reaction with diethylmalonate 13. opportune amine (CH3)2CO, 60°C MW, min, b) opportune amine (CH3)2CO, 60°C MW, ii. NH2NH2; iii. compound 9d has a broad antiviral activity against enveloped viruses. it showed a potent antiviral activity against all enveloped viruses tested at not cytotoxic doses. compound 9d retained its antiviral activity also against HSV-2 acyclovir resistant strain. the antiviral activity is directed to the virus rather than the cell, but is maintained in post-treatment assays. we observed a significant reduction of activity in the during-infection assay (EC50 = 0.147 M), if compared to the pre-incubation assay. compound 9d was added on cells 2 h before infection (PRE-TREATMENT CELLS) and subsequently the inocula were removed. cells were fixed and stained 24 h later and plaques were counted. percentage of infection was calculated comparing wells to wells treated with equal volumes of solvent. 105 pfu of HSV-2 were incubated for 0, 15’, 30’, 45’ or 60’ at 37°C with 10 M, 5 M or 1 M of compound and subsequently titrated on Vero cells. in this condition the infectivity was not regained further verifying the permanent virucidal activity. the compound is not altering viral binding capability, differently from heparin, a known attachment inhibitor [16]. with this assay, the signal from the virus could be related to virus in the cytoplasm or blocked in the endosomes. the treatment with acidic glycine is affecting only the virus at the surface of the cell. compound 9d is a model lipid substrate, incorporated in a DPPC liposomes. the lipid peroxidation was evaluated by monitoring the production of the lipid degradation end-product malondialdehyde. the results of the TBA assay suggest the peroxidant activity of the compound. a broad-spectrum activity against a panel of seven enveloped viruses suggests a mechanism of action on the viral envelope that is affecting viral and cell membrane fusion. this is of particular interest if we consider that all the recent epidemics of emerging and re-emerging viruses are caused by enveloped viruses. the contents of the vessel were stirred by a rotating magnetic plate and a teflon-coated magnetic stir bar. all experiments were performed using a stirring option, whereby the contents of the vessel were stirred by a rotating magnetic plate located below the floor of the microwave cavity. the crude product was purified by flash chromatography using PE/EtOAc = 4:1 as eluent to yield the wished product 5 as a light orange solid (yield: 96%); mp = 150°C (decomposition); 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) the reaction mixture was heated at 90°C for 10 min under microwave irradiation. the reaction mixture was evaporated to NH4SCN (5,17 mmol, 1.2 eq) was added in 3 mL of acetone. opportune amine (1.00 eq) respectively benzylamine for 8a, and phenethylamine for 8b, was added. resulting suspension was filtered, and the precipitate washed with H2O and CH3OH, to furnish pure 8a and 8b as white solids. opportune thioureido derivative (11a or 11b) (1.61 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of hydrazine monohydrate. solution stirred at RT for 3 h. then 5 mL of fuming hydrochloric acid were added. ourea compound (12a or 12b) (1.20 mmol) and diethylmalonate 13 (2.41 mmol) were added. the mixture was refluxed under Argon atmosphere. the solvent was removed at reduced pressure and the residue was solubilized. at 70°C overnight, 3 mL of HCl were added and the precipitate was filtered at reduced pressure to give a solid that was washed with H2O, CH3OH and hexane. the resulting precipitate was filtered at reduced pressure to give a solid that washed with hexane. low-passage human embryonic lung fibroblasts (HELFs) were grown as monolayers in Eagle's minimal essential medium (Gibco/BRL, Gaithersburg, MD) in the same conditions as described above. human epithelial adenocarcinoma HeLa cells were propagated in DMEM. the 293TT cell line, derived from human embryonic kidney cells transformed with the simian virus 40 (SV40) large T antigen, was cultured as monolayer in medium in DMEM supplemented with Glutamax-I (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) and nonessential aminoacids. EM containing 0.5 mg trypsin per mL was propagated on vero cells. adenovirus 5 encoding GFP (GFP-Ad5) was propagated and titrated by plaque assay. cell viability was measured using the MTS assay. the 50% cytotoxic concentrations (CC50) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were determined using Prism software. for compound 9d a continuous incubation of 1, 2, 3 and 4 days on vero cells was carried in order to evaluate the toxicity after long exposure. the following day increasing concentrations of compounds were mixed with HCMV (MOI 0.005) and incubated for 1 h at 37°C. the mixtures were then added to the cells, which were then incubated at 37°C for 3 h. monolayers were then washed and overlaid with 1.2% methylcellulose medium supplemented with 3% FCS and 1mM sodium pyruvate. monolayers were then washed and overlaid with medium. cells were then fixed with cold acetone–methanol and viral titers were determined by indirect immunostaining using the monoclonal antibody mab-0036. infected cells were infected with HSV-2 (MOI 0.01) for 2 h at 37°C. inocula were removed, cells were washed and HSV-2 was added on cells for 2 h at 37°C. the same protocol described above was followed. the following day 10 M of compound and HSV-2 (MOI 10) were incubated for 1 h at 37°C and subsequently added on cells for 1 h at 4°C. cells were then washed and shifted at 37°C for 1.5 h or 4 h. qPCR Cells subjected to binding assays were then lysed and subjected to total DNA/RNA extraction and subsequently subjected to qPCR using as primers 5’- CCGTCAGCACCTTCATCGA -3’ and 5’-CGCTGGACCTCCGTGTAGTC -3’. the results were normalized according to values of rnasep. DPPC liposomes were prepared with the thin film evaporation method. they were used to mimic a phospholipid bilayer, and to dissolve linoleic acid. the mixture was stirred and heated in water bath at 37°C. the calibration curve of TBA-MDA-TBA complex was obtained using a MDA precursor 1,1,3,3-tetraethoxypropane in an equimolecular reaction. for this purpose, standard solutions of 1,1,3,3-tetraethoxypropane within the concentration range 5–250 M were prepared. chromatography was carried out using Merck 60 silica gel, 23–400 mesh. chroomatographic purifications were performed on columns packed with Merck 60 silica gel, 23–400 mesh. the reaction went to completion and was quenched with H2O and 2N HCl. then EtOAc was added and the mixture was stirred until the two layers became clear. the aqueous layer was extracted three times with EtOAc, then the organic phase was washed several times with H2O and brine, dried over Na2SO4. IAV H1N1 inhibition assays MDCK cells were pre-plated in 96-well plates. the following day increasing concentrations of compounds were mixed with IAV (MOI 0.05) and incubated for 1 h at 37°C. mixtures were subsequently added to the cells for 1 h at 37°C. the following day virus infectivity was activated by adding 5 g porcine trypsin (Sigma)/mL for 30 min at 37°C. the mixtures were subsequently added to the cells, which were then incubated at 37°C for 1 h. the percentages of infection were calculated by comparing GFP positive cells in treated and untreated wells. the following day, increasing concentrations of compounds were mixed with IAV (MOI 0.05) and incubated for 1 h at 37°C. the mixtures were subsequently added to the cells for 1 h at 37°C. cells were incubated for 1 h at 37°C and subsequently added on cells for 2 h at 4°C. cells were then fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde, air dried, and blocked with 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS)–Tween. 105 PFU of HSV2 plus 10 M or different concentration of compound were added to MEM and mixed in a total volume of 100 L. the mixtures were incubated for different times at 37°C then diluted serially to the non-inhibitory concentration of test compound on cells or in tubes for additional 1, 2, 3 or 4 hours. the residual viral infectivity was determined by viral plaque assay. an in vitro lipoperoxidation test was carried out. the potential oxidative effect of 9d was evaluated toward the oxidation of linoleic acid. the lipoperoxidation of linoleic acid was determined using the TBA assay. 100 l of the 9d DMSO solution were incubated at 37°C for 30 minutes. a volume of the blank and 9d samples (0.2 mL) were withdrawn and introduced in a glass tube closed with a screw cap. the mixture was stirred and heated in water bath at 95–100°C for 45 min. the peroxidation experiment was carried out using a control sample containing 0.05% w/w of ()--tocopherol, molecule with antioxidant properties. results are mean and SD of 3 independent experiments.
